articles.headline: China Is Eager to Bring High-Speed Rail Expertise to the U.S.
articles.snippet: China is poised to play a role in supplying the technology  to build high-speed rail lines in California.
articles.abstract: China is poised to play a role in supplying the technology  to build high-speed rail lines in California.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Nearly 150 years after American railroads brought in thousands of Chinese laborers to build rail lines across the West, China is poised once again to play a role in American rail construction. But this time, it would be an entirely different role: supplying the technology, equipment and engineers to build high-speed rail lines.

articles.headline: Hot Spot Shortcut, in the Weeds
articles.snippet: Cisco introduces the Valet, a stripped-down router that won’t frustrate a non-engineer who tries to set it up. Sounds perfect, yes? Well...
articles.abstract: Cisco introduces the Valet, a stripped-down router that won’t frustrate a non-engineer who tries to set it up. Sounds perfect, yes? Well...
articles.lead_paragraph: You want to hear a really scary statistic? Twenty-five percent.

articles.headline: Free Report on Credit? No Longer
articles.snippet: To sidestep Federal Trade Commission rules, freecreditreport.com is now charging $1 for credit reports.
articles.abstract: To sidestep Federal Trade Commission rules, freecreditreport.com is now charging $1 for credit reports.
articles.lead_paragraph: The credit report you get from freecreditreport.com is no longer free, no matter what that Web address promises.

articles.headline: China’s Censors Tackle and Trip Over the Internet
articles.snippet: The Communist Party’s censorship machine is highly sophisticated in some ways, remarkably crude in others.
articles.abstract: The Communist Party’s censorship machine is highly sophisticated in some ways, remarkably crude in others.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Michael Wines, Sharon LaFraniere and Jonathan Ansfield and written by Mr. Wines.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines, Sharon LaFraniere and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: Geithner to Visit China, in Sign of Warming Relations
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner will meet on Thursday with the Chinese vice prime minister, who is influential in setting economic policy.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner will meet on Thursday with the Chinese vice prime minister, who is influential in setting economic policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — In a sign of improving economic relations between the United States and China, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner will meet the Chinese vice prime minister in Beijing on Thursday on his way back to the United States from India, a Treasury spokesman said here on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: A Mine Boss Inspires Fear, but Pride, Too
articles.snippet: Don L. Blankenship, the president of the Massey Energy Company, is a hard-edged man in a hard-edged industry.
articles.abstract: Don L. Blankenship, the president of the Massey Energy Company, is a hard-edged man in a hard-edged industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTCOAL, W.Va. — Since Monday’s mine explosion, Don L. Blankenship, the chief executive of the Massey Energy Company, which owns the Upper Big Branch mine, has appeared several times before the cameras. But he has said very little, his face seeming almost expressionless as he quietly answers questions about his concern for miner safety.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and John Leland

articles.headline: United Is in Merger Talks With US Airways
articles.snippet: As most airlines lose money, two see a chance to reverse their fortunes with greater economy of scale.
articles.abstract: As most airlines lose money, two see a chance to reverse their fortunes with greater economy of scale.
articles.lead_paragraph: United Airlines and US Airways are in merger talks that, if successful, would create the nation’s second-biggest airline. It is the third time in a decade that they have tried to make a deal.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Assessing Response to Illegal Smoke and Quip
articles.snippet: There seemed to be little second-guessing of the broad security alert in response to a man smoking on a plane.
articles.abstract: There seemed to be little second-guessing of the broad security alert in response to a man smoking on a plane.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When an illicit pipe and a foolish joke aboard an airliner touches off a national megascare, scrambling fighter jets and F.B.I. agents, alerting all 4,900 flights in progress and unleashing a media flood, does that mean the security system works?

articles.headline: Panel Criticizes Oversight of Citi by 2 Executives
articles.snippet: Charles O. Prince III and Robert E. Rubin came under withering criticism during a hearing into the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Charles O. Prince III and Robert E. Rubin came under withering criticism during a hearing into the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two men who steered Citigroup into the eye of the financial storm offered a striking contrast on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: U.S. Retailers Report Strong Gains for March
articles.snippet: The nation’s retailers reported their strongest monthly sales growth in a decade.
articles.abstract: The nation’s retailers reported their strongest monthly sales growth in a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s retailers reported their strongest monthly sales growth in a decade on Thursday, with robust gains in virtually every category of merchandise and every type of store.

articles.headline: China Seems Set to Loosen Hold on Its Currency
articles.snippet: Beijing is said to be ready to announce  that the currency will be allowed more variation and a small jump against the dollar.
articles.abstract: Beijing is said to be ready to announce  that the currency will be allowed more variation and a small jump against the dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government is preparing to announce in the coming days that it will allow its currency to strengthen slightly and vary more from day to day, people with knowledge of the emerging consensus in Beijing said on Thursday. The move would help ease tension with the Obama administration about the United States’ huge trade deficit with China.
